You make a valid argument that overusing a label can sometimes create a desensitizing effect. Your assertion that people would have simply shrugged their shoulders over 9/11 if "terrorism" was an overused part of the lexicon in 2001 is risible.  I'm a firm believer in the power of language, but you're giving a word way to much credit here.

The word "terrorism" can certainly be a powerful and influential word when used in rhetoric, or anywhere at all for that matter, however any word or phrase can have a great amount of impact if used in a forceful speech given by someone with a lot of power or a high social standing. Terrorism does have a broad definition, but I define it as simply an act of inciting terror on a large number of people on a grand scale. The word terror itself means to have a fearful and more importantly long lasting effect on a person's memory or psyche. That's why we all refer to 9/11 as a terrorist attack, because so many were affected by it, and the event is remembered by all Americans who were alive during the time.
If we were to call any act of violence that occurred as a terrorist attack, the word terror, and by extension terrorism, would lose all meaning. That's why people should be more careful using the word "terrorism" in conversation, formal speeches, or really anywhere else so casually. If every act of violence, large scale of not, is treated as a terrorist attack, then events such as 9/11 wouldn't be remembered as terrifying and as important as they actually were and then we would lose inspiration to fight against real terrorism.

Kate, I'd be curious to know what options you think her medical team might better inform her of? Are you in the field? Because maybe you could let my team at UCSF know, since I was presented with the same set of options as the author, and you clearly know something the rest of us don't.

87 percent risk is dire, and the options are limited. Don't dismiss the author's predicament until the time bomb is ticking in your own breasts.

There may be another way to protect against getting breast and ovarian cancer which is in trials right now - Metformin. This is a cheap, widely used diabetes drug that halves the risk of developing cancer across the board in the people who take it regularly. It has a terrific safety profile, and after the initial three weeks has no side effects for most people..

There are already trials going on to see whether it works to prevent cancer for people carrying the BRCA 1 mutation, sponsored by the National Cancer Institute: (http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01905046?term=metformin+breast+can...

There is already evidence that Metformin may especially help people carrying BRCA1: http://omicsonline.org/2161-1041/2161-1041-1-104.php?aid=4904

I am a stage 4 cancer patient with a previously untreatable, uniformly fatal cancer with a rapid, dire prognosis, but am participating in a clinical trial simply adding Metformin to a chemotherapy treatment that does not stop this cancer by itself, and so far my aggressive, deadly cancer has regressed by a third and is holding stable.

None of this is proven yet, but please know that there are options in the drug pipeline that may prove to be a better option than radical prophylactic surgeries that have been the only alternative in the past. I encourage everyone with BRCA1 to stay posted.

You are in good company, not alone, with many fighting for you.

Unless one writes articles such as this under an assumed name, a writer is voluntarily disclosing to the world that  she believes cancer is in her future.  This information is now easily available to every prospective employer.  If a person such as the writer is not hired for a job because her employer now knows that there is an increased likelihood of illness, how in the world would she ever know this?   Unless you have the massive wealth of an Angelina Jolie, disclosing this type of personal health information in the pages of the NY Times is ill-advised not just for you, but for your relatives and children who must now live with the potential consequences of the author's decision.

Both BRCA genes are dominant, so you only need one mutation to increase your risk. Each mutation has it's own probability of causing cancer, otherwise known as penetrance. This is why the ranges are so broad.

There is zero information here to surmise that Ms. Cunha has both mutations, inherited by each parent. She has clearly stated she has a BrCa 1 mutation.  I assure you Mr. Bradley, there is plenty of risk of "female" cancers just from that one for the author to be concerned with.

I am astonished by the variety of responses to this article, written by someone with an almost incredible diagnosis.  I would, however, like to ask if the author might clarify a point with extremely important implications for others who are or will be suffering from the problems associated with mutations in the "breast cancer" genes -- there are two known, important genes (BRCA1 and BRCA2) known to be associated with high risks of breast, uterine, and ovarian cancer.  Given the author's stated risks of developing one or more of these cancers it would appear that she is the recipient (from her parent(s))of defective genes in both BRCA1 and BRCA2.  The reason I believe the clarification to be of value to others is the relatively lower (not small, just lower) risk of developing these "female" cancers when one has a defect in one or the other (but not both) of these genes.  The risk is still, unfortunately, high when one has a single BRCA gene defect, but not (as far as I understand things) the extraordinary risk the author runs (which has been clearly established).

Bill L: I agree, and I want to add that I have never seen a novel that won a good review based on its price either.

I read that Jeff Bezos made all his employees read "Howard's End" so that they would be able to appreciate fine literature.

That makes me chuckle, because Bezos is by nature a Wilcox, a callous defender of the brutish capitalism of the Empire, and Forster's novel is about how callousness and greed eventually bring about the end of the Wilcoxes.

Good for you and I hope you and your neighbors will continue to patronize your fine community book seller.  But like millions of others, I live in an area that does NOT have a good local bookstore.  (Instead we have a woeful outlet of a national chain.)  I write only to point out that the fact YOU have another option is not relevant to those who do not.

Good column, with which I agree.
We are fortunate to have an excellent local bookstore right in the center of our little town (Ridgefield, Ct). They can get virtually any book by the next day, and the store is a delight to browse in, and the staff is great.

The cost of the books might be a dollar or two higher (probably about equal to shipping), but I will happily pay that difference to support such a valuable local retailer.

As with many other discount retailers, doing business with Amazon has lots of hidden costs... to authors, to artists, to manufacturers. There are more important things than getting something for the absolute lowest price.

I have a customer's loyalty to Amazon for the many good things it has done for me. Yet I agree with Professor Krugman. What did the Standard Oil case(s) served to remind the nation? That businesses exist only through licenses granted by the states, and the federal government has the constitutional authority to regulate both interstate and international trade. So legal equality, 'equal justice under law', is at the core of the right to do business.

Amazon has become a powerful retailer, to their credit. But with great authority comes great responsibility. Will Amazon now extend such anti-competitive practices to other areas of its retailing?

Anti-competitive? How can that be, when Amazon does not compete with Hachette in publishing? Because by interfering in its role as a key channel to market it is favoring those publishers it prefers, giving them unfair advantage over Hachette.

Just as in the struggle to require internet providers to provide a level playing field for content, so exactly Amazon must strive to treat its content providers and other product providers equally. Standard Oil once arranged a kick-back to themselves from railroads for every barrel of other companies' oil shipped on those rails. Today Amazon is the rails, and in the Hachette case it is competing not only with other retail shippers, but unfairly steering its customers away from Hachette both through availability and through comparative shipping times, 'John D. Bezos'?

Right...congress represents monopolies instead of regulating them. Excess profits of monopolies then pay for lawmakers' campaigns, leading to lower taxes, offshoring of profits and of US jobs. So lawmakers enrich themselves while removing both jobs and revenue from their own nation which elects them. And now voters suffering the effects of this abuse may vote for the party most responsible for it. What words could describe this surreal form of democracy?

Citizens United lies in the face of the reality of corporations: they're not people, and their policies arise in and come from the minds of the men and women who conceive of them, manage them, and direct them.

Amazon is the creation of Jeff Bezos and Jeff Bezos, like masterminds of monopoly and trust before him not only finds nothing "wrong" in either destroying or controlling competition, but in fact sees it as a logical business practice.

The Sherman Anti-trust Act and the Clayton Act succeeded in-law in derailing such practices "by corporations." But they did nothing to change the minds of individuals who cultivate and practice such business behavior.

Jeff Bezos, his direct reports, and his board members are the faces of reckless, ruthless business practice, not Amazon.

I buy gas from Chevron stations and U.S. Steel's products are in objects I own. And I have been buying from Amazon since the beginning.

But I don't admire Amazon. And I dislike that I have lived to see my nation and society slide like a muddy slope into a time when Trusts and Monopolies are not only not attacked by Congress, Courts and Presidents, but instead are represented by them in opposition to the goodwill of the majority.

$23 million is a "respectable" opening-weekend showing for a generic B-movie action-flick that doesn't star someone of the caliber of Brad Pitt. For a purportedly realistic war film possessed of deep thoughts, Oscar ambitions AND Brad Pitt it's a pretty weak total. Whatever happened to "Boxtrolls," by the way? Despite the good reviews it received, kids and their families seem to have stayed away after the first weekend. How come?

I read more today than I ever have, and I've been reading since I was quite young. Those "100 books everyone should read before they die" lists? I seldom come across one where I haven't already read 90 or so of the deathless books. But nowadays, of the reading I do, I read maybe 20-30 books a year. And most of those books are, frankly, potboilers. You know what I do read? The internet. Politics, economics, history, articles on my field of work -- I spend more time reading than I do sleeping, more than I did as a kid when I would stay up until the early morning hours reading sci-fi, or "good" novels, and then drag through a boring day of school reading pointless garbage. Technology has opened up vast opportunities to me I never would have had access to before.
Once upon a time, all educated people could quote extensively from the bible, from Milton, Shakespeare, perhaps Homer or Marcus Aurelius -- you get the point. But that was about all they knew, from an academic standpoint. Nowadays, nobody can quote from those authors -- but an educated person today knows far, far more than even the most educated person did back then. So don't look down on "the kids of today." Three hundred years ago, someone (in reality far less literate than you by today's standards) might have thought you a dunce if they made a pun using some biblical reference that flew right over your head, as though borne by the winds of Aeolus.

Amazon is seeking lower prices for two primary reasons: one, to increase its profits, now or in the future and, most importantly, to increase its power in the marketplace.

I have been involved in start-up businesses most of my adult life and in the process I have met a lot of other people starting businesses. They almost always talk about their plans to "dominate" a particular business segment. It is kind of like the normal dream: we are going to start small, grow fast and knock everyone else out of the way. It seldom happens, but the dream lives.

Amazon has reached such a position and wants more. How much more? Anything it can get. Everything.

Most companies, large and small, are a bit more subtle than Amazon in what it is doing to publishers. Most corporations want, at least, to pretend they are good citizens. Amazon acts as though it believes it is untouchable. This is somewhat understandable because online retailing, along with the Internet itself, had a favored position as a center of American innovation. It is time for this "wonder of it all" period to come to an end (that was the '90s) and face reality, for Amazon and the rest of us.

Amazon acquired Zappos in 2009. Another company with great customer service is Audible. Amazon bought that company as well.

In my experience, Amazon generally offers great customer service, especially with returns. But it still has monopoly power in the book sector, and that's the problem.

I'm a liberal. How Amazon treats it's employees, as long as it's within the law, is it's business and does not come under the scope of this essay, which is about illegal business practices. People need to distinguish the distinctions in a legal argument and not have legal questions turn into mob popularity contests.

Don't sound much like a 'liberal'.  Yeah, child labor was once lawful, but it was/is highly unethical.  Similarly, subjecting employees to harsh working conditions might be lawful, it doesn't make it right or ethical, and it should matter to all of us!

CK, just how a company treats it's workers is WELL within the scope of this essay. The problem is that Amazon does Not follow the law in regards to it's employees any more than it follows the law on Monopolistic behavior and this has become apparent to most people when they take a clear, unbiased look at their business practices both in the Marketplace and with their employees. It is telling that it is In Court, Presently, BECAUSE of their treatment of their workforce.

This is a large part of those "side issues" that Dr. Krugman just happens to point out that he did not want to get tangled in, even though it is a part of the whole web that is Amazon. Presently there IS legal argument concerning their treatment of the workforce and thus, would fall under the 'Illegal Business Practice' label. It is not a 'mob popularity contest' to point out such truths, as they used to say on Dragnet: "All we know are the facts, ma'am."

Let's also not forget how inhumanly Amazon is treating its employees in its fulfillment centers.  Amazon equals Walmart in the use of monitoring technologies to track the minute-by-minute movements and performance of employees and in settings that go beyond the assembly line to include their movement between loading and unloading docks, between packing and unpacking stations, and to and from the miles of shelving at what Amazon calls its “fulfillment centers”.  Amazon is in court defending its predatory behavior toward low-paid hourly warehouse workers. The contempt that it displays toward its wholesalers and customers extends to its workforce as well, resulting in a trifecta of abusive behavior

The New York Times may employ “marginal” journalists as sports writers, but no school in the FBS puts “marginal” players on the field no matter how stellar their academic achievement or pristine their conduct. Golson was expelled from Notre Dame for an academic violation and was barred from the team for an entire season. He took responsibility for his transgression. Rather than transfer to another school to continue his football apprenticeship, he decided to spend a year beefing up his academics and honing his athletic skills. Only after successfully being readmitted to the university, did he compete again on the field. Despite a sexual assault investigation, a proven theft from a local grocery store an autograph scam and childish pranks with a weapon, Winston was suspended for one game! Golson outplayed Winston on Saturday night and but for a questionable pass interference call, would have won that game. Notre Dame graduates 97% of its student athletes; FSU ranks at 56%. Golson will graduate from a prestigious university. Can the same be said of Winston? Your attempt to make Golson the equivalent of Winston misses the mark in so many ways.
Go Irish!

Hmmm let’s address the big elephant in the room that you seem to skirt around.  The student athletes of this caliber have the opportunity to go to ANY university they choose.  They are heavily recruited by most and will look at different factors in deciding where to take their talents.  I know we like to ignore the obvious but the overwhelming majority, if not 100% of the players in this exclusive demographic see college football as a stepping stone to the NFL.  While we like to see them graduate they don't because they "do their time" at the college level and move on to the NFL.  So congratulations on graduating your athletes but we can't ignore the fact that when it comes to sending players to the NFL, the main objective for MOST players of this caliber, FSU does a better job than Notre Dame.

They do not all have the opportunity to go to any university they choose.  There still are schools that do enforce a certain level of  achievement, and at those schools transcripts still count, athletic ability notwithstanding. The fact also remains that very few student-athletes -- and in many cases, the "student" part of that is largely ignored -- actually go on to the NFL. The low graduation rates do not necessarily equate to players not obtaining a degree because they've been drafted by the NFL; it often means that the athletes simply did not graduate and then are just done at the school once their eligibility runs out. No NFL career and no degree, and apparently no great amount of concern about that from some of the schools.

"Perhaps it is too much to expect from a college student to soak in the limelight on the field and avoid the spotlight off it."  That is a huge understatement,  especially in light of the unique person that Jameis Winston has proven to be.  FSU fans have been ecstatic our his on-field performance and dismayed about some of his poor decisions off the field.  As one of those fans, I'm rooting for his success in both areas, but recent revelations of don't give me a lot of confidence.
